text: FOOMY PUNCH! :D
author: sarcomaful

text: beautiful
author: alexis alzate

text: I think the best thing about Lufia (at least Lufia 2; never played the first) was how the dungeons weren't just a series of corridors that needed to be navigated to get from Point A to Point B; they were actual puzzles that required thought to clear. So there was that little bit of extra pride in getting through them, because it wasn't just a matter of over-leveling the enemies to get past a given section of the game.
author: WhiteTigerShiro

text:
I played Lufia 2 before I ever knew the first one existed, it was really weird playing them in "chronological" order. Fantastic games the both of them.

Also one of the first RPG series (other than the Phantasy Star) I ever played that offered direct continuity with each other, way cool.
author: Marshall Price

text: I've never played either Lufia 1 or 2. Which one should I play first?

text: @drunyon214 Lufia 1 is pretty good. Lufia 2 is a godlike video game and one of my absolute favorite SNES games. I like the equipment specials and capsule monsters most.

author: garfreeek

text: @garfreeek The playstation uses the same chip for sound that the snes used. Afterall sony did supply everything for nintendo back in the day. It was the president of nintendo at the time that backstabbed sony right before unveiling the playstation to the public...see nintendo worked with phillips to create the 64DD which was the first ever cd playing system...it was a failure in japan as well as the addon for the 64 didnt sell. Sony heard of this and pretty much ripped the contract and cut ties with nintendo and instead of nintendo getting the nintendo play station as their new system...they entered the market with their new console using the exact same specs for sound that the snes used. Hence why they sound so similar. The more ya know eh. We can all thank the old president for poor marketing and business skills. I hope i educated you on this matter.

author: Lockhart1433

text: I have a short list of games I can replay every year or other year, and an even shorter list of RPGs. Lufia II being in that short list shows how much I like it. It just has a mix of everything done right, with the quality puzzles being a highlight when compared to other RPGs. The music is of course another big highlight (the boss and Sinistrals battle themes being some of my favorites ever).
